title: 103_hr4962
content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. Membership includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Steering committee appoints advisory committees. Ex officio members include a US House of Representatives Member. The Management Conference, including a Member of the United States House of Representatives, is tasked with publishing a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin within a year of enactment. The plan will clarify duties, funding methods, and schedules for programs and projects. The Management Conference, with input from the public, will develop a pollution prevention and control plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin, incorporating environmental management concepts and strategies for reducing pollution. The plan will undergo public review and approval by the Administrator within 30 days of publication. Upon approval of the Plan by the Administrator, it will be considered an approved management program under section 319(h) and a comprehensive conservation and management plan under section 320 of this Act. The Plan will then be implemented. The Administrator may provide grant assistance to water pollution control agencies for the development of the Plan, including research, surveys, studies, modeling, and technical work. The federal share of grants under this subsection shall not exceed 70% of development costs, with the condition that non-Federal sources provide the remaining share. In-kind services may be used for the non-Federal share. The Administrator can establish terms and conditions for grant administration. The term "Coeur d'Alene Basin" refers to a specific watershed in northern Idaho. This section does not affect the jurisdiction or powers of any US or State department/agency, or any entity related to the Coeur d'Alene Basin created by treaty or memorandum. The Environmental Protection Agency is authorized to receive necessary appropriations for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out the provisions of this section as a signatory to treaties or memoranda. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by developing an integrated geographic information system, converting recording sites to monitoring stations, and establishing additional monitoring sites for groundwater mapping. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program and conduct a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to conduct surveys of various species, including Federal threatened and endangered species, migratory bird populations, and fishery resources, to improve their health and disseminate information on their status. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to conduct surveys of fishery resources, disseminate information to interested parties, and periodically update a survey of fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out these activities. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with other trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes creating a geographical information system inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas for cleanup. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, stream restoration, monitoring of restored areas, development of a land management plan, and creation of a geographical information system for cultural and ecological resources. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes coordinating management of ecological resources, developing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans, monitoring wildlife areas for effectiveness, creating an integrated public recreation management plan, and implementing a lake and river information system. The Director of the United States Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste areas, data management, accepting contaminated lands for restoration, design and construction of restoration projects, and implementing a lake and river information program. Authorization of Appropriations: The Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management, is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 1995-2002 to carry out restoration activities, land management plans, and maintenance of restored public lands. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
